jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #173:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow-site/pull/173#issuecomment-1000379659


   > Concern: apache/arrow-site repository size will be increased steadily. We may need to remove the previous commit to update dev docs (only if the previous commit is an update dev docs commit) before we update dev docs.
   
   Yes, this is indeed a problem (I raised a similar concern when adding the multiple versions of the docs, as that also steadily increase the repo size). For the dev docs specifically, we of course only need to have the latest version and can thus overwrite / clean-up the git history to avoid increasing the repo size. 
   
   The options I was thinking about:
   
   - In the action, remove the history of just the dev docs directory with something like https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo/. This rewrites history and thus requires force pushing from inside the action.
   - In the action, we could also completely re-initialize the asf-site branch from the current content + updated dev docs (in the idea that we mostly care about history in the mater branch, and less so in the asf-site branch?). But similarly as above, this requires force pushing from inside the action (so probably not much advantage for this option compared to the one above)
   - Keep the action as is (additional commit, so no need to force push), but from time to time clean-up the asf-site branch and force push manually (we could have a similar script to remove the history in the dev docs directory)
   
   Your idea of removing the previous commit to update dev docs (only if the previous commit is an update dev docs commit) could also be an option, but that will miss some of those commits, and also requires force pushing.
   
   I was a bit hesitant to take any option that requires a force push (so didn't yet add anything in this PR, leaving the manual clean-up from time to time), but maybe that's not actually a problem?

fields.description: This will help catch problems with the generated documentation prior to release time, and also allow users to read the latest prose documentation.
fields.summary: [Doc] Publish nightly documentation against master somewhere

comments.body: With a lot of nightly things, this will require some blob storage where a technical user (read Travis) can upload to.
cc [~kszucs]
Where do We want to host it?

I don't know. It could be github-pages, but the setup is a bit unorthodox (we would probably have to create a separate repo for doc builds and push to it automatically). I don't think ReadTheDocs allows pushing already built docs.

There's a simplistic [Sphinx extension|https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/githubpages.html] too :)

At the moment I'm uploading them manually to http://arrow.apache.org/docs/latest/ We could also auto-upload it there but that requires someone to place his ASF credentials for uploading where the cron-job runs.

Since the documentation is kind of large (10s of megabytes), we might consider hosting on a different domain under a simple HTTP server. Otherwise the site of arrow-site will grow really massive over time
[~wesmckinn] Any ideas on which infrastructure we could do this? Should we concat INFRA for this or do we have other means?

We could set up Netlify static hosting on a different domain/subdomain and push the nightly build from one of our CUDA-enabled servers. This is for development anyway, so there's not much benefit to having the nightly docs hosted on ASF infrastructure?
cc [~npr]
My idea is to update arrow-site to host the documentation for the last three releases and one for master which could be updated regularly by a github actions cron job.
The docs need CUDA so not sure that GHA cron will work unless self-hosted.
IMO having some automated nightly docs without CUDA is better than not having them at all because we insist on building with CUDA.
cc [~amol-]

We don't need CUDA to build the docs. A crossbow nightly task could push the nightly docs to somewhere, preferably to a subdir in apache/arrow-site, though we'd need to have a version selector somewhere on the page.
Indeed, CUDA is not strictly needed, but then API docs will be incomplete. That said, it's still much better than nothing.

> A crossbow nightly task could push the nightly docs to somewhere, preferably to a subdir in apache/arrow-site

We already have a nightly task to build the docs, so I assume we can use that one to push the docs it built to github pages. 

When pushing to the asf-site branch of the repo, I think we will need to re-initialize the branch (or squash) every time, as otherwise adding a commit daily with the full doc build might quickly lead to a large repo size? (although it's maybe not too bad, and can first see how it goes)

I would propose to push the nightly docs in a subdirectory like "/docs/dev/" or "/docs/version/dev" (and we can later add the builds for released versions under "docs/5.0/" or "docs/version/5.0").

>  though we'd need to have a version selector somewhere on the page.

We would certainly need that eventually (especially when keeping the docs for past released versions), and there are several other doc sites using the same sphinx theme that have this. But I don't think we necessarily need to fix that before tackling this issue (for the nightly dev docs, it's a single url that we can document that can be checked). 
I will open a separate JIRA for a version selector.

In ARROW-14986, [~kou] updated the release scripts to use the built docs from the crossbow build for the rc / release (which are added to the crossbow "release" assets, eg https://github.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/releases/tag/actions-1300-azure-test-ubuntu-default-docs for the latest run, all built docs can be downloaded as zipped archive "docs.tar.gz"). 

We can probably use the same strategy for dev docs as well? For example have a cron job on arrow-site that downloads the latest assets from crossbow, and adds then to the github-pages branch in a /docs/dev/ directory.

It will work. But we need to use the asf-site branch to publish to https://arrow.apache.org/docs/ .
See also: https://github.com/apache/arrow-site/blob/master/.github/workflows/deploy.yml#L41-L49

Concern: apache/arrow-site repository size will be increased steadily. We may need to remove the previous commit to update dev docs (only if the previous commit is a update dev docs commit) before we update dev docs.
Nightly docs are now available at https://arrow.apache.org/docs/dev/ !
Wow! Is it planned for the dev docs to appear in the version dropdown in the stable docs? (e.g. https://arrow.apache.org/docs/index.html)
Yes, but I also noticed that that's not yet working. Next thing to do :)
https://github.com/apache/arrow-site/pull/177 should take care of adding dev to the version dropdown
